OniconF1000FlowMeter.doc:
F-1000 Series Turbine Flow Meters.

ONICON’s F-1000 Series is a family of insertion and inline style turbine flow
meters that provide accurate, reliable flow measurement in a variety of applications.
Each model utilizes ONICON’s patented electronic turbine rotation sensing system
and unique low mass turbine design that is accurate over wide flow ranges with
excellent low flow measurement capability.

ONICON F-1000 Series Turbine Flow Meters are designed to work in pipe sizes ranging
from ¾" to 72" in diameter (1" for copper). Uses for the F-1000 Series turbine
flow meters include:
  - Chilled Water
  - Hot Water
  - Condenser Water
  - Domestic Water
  - Process Cooling
  - Steam Condensate and Brine

OniconF4300FlowMeter.doc:
Onicon F-4300 Clamp-on Ultrasonic Flow Meter / Thermal Energy Measurement System.

**Ideal Solution for Retrofits and Baseline Monitoring** Clamp-on transducers allow
for quick and easy installation with no system shutdown and no pressure drop. Each
meter is provided with a built-in 128 megabyte data logger, making it an ideal solution
for baseline monitoring.

**Simple to Install and Commission**  Every ONICON F-4300 is individually configured
and programmed using customer specific application data. Complex field programming
is not required.

**High Confidence and Reliability** ONICON provides transducers that are optimized
for specific pipe conditions, providing a strong, stable signal with an outstanding
signal-to-noise ratio.

**Native BACnet and MODBUS Communications**  The F-4300 is provided with a single
RS485 output that can be configured to operate on BACnet® MS/TP or MODBUS® RTU networks.

OniconFT3000FlowMeter.doc:
FT-3000 Series Inline Electromagnetic Flow Meters.

ONICON's FT-3000 Series family of Inline Electromagnetic Flow Meters are
suitable for measuring electrically conductive liquids in a wide variety
of commercial HVAC applications. The FT-3000 series provides analog and
digital outputs for flow rate and programmable pulse outputs for flow
totalization and/or alarms. The FT-3000 Inline Electromagnetic Flow Meters
are available in various sizes and arrive factory-configured for ease of
installation and start-up. All FT-3000 series flow meters are wet calibrated
in a flow laboratory against standards that are directly traceable to
international standards. A certificate of calibration accompanies every
meter.

Typical applications include monitoring of cooling water, heating water,
condenser water and domestic water.

OniconF3500FlowMeter.doc:
F-3500 Insertion Electromagnetic Flow Meter.

ONICON's F-3500 Series Insertion Electromagnetic Flow Meters are suitable
for measuring electrically conductive liquids in a wide variety of applications.
Each F-3500 provides a single analog output for flow rate, a high resolution
frequency output to drive peripheral devices, a scalable pulse output for
totalization, and an empty pipe alarm. It is available for use in pipes ranging
in size from 1¼ " to 72 " in diameter. The F-3500 Insertion Electromagnetic
Flow Meter features ONICON's unique hot tap design that allows for easy
insertion or removal from the pipe without the use of special tools and without
disrupting flow. The low maintenance design is provided ready-to-use without
the need for field programming.   The FB-3500 Electromagnetic Flow Meter is
available for bi-directional flow applications. It provides an analog output
for flow rate, a contact closure output to indicate flow direction and separate
pulse outputs to totalize forward and reverse flow.

The F-3500 is ideal for chilled water, hot water, domestic water, condenser
water, water/glycol, and municipal water applications.

OniconFP4400FlowMeter.doc:
FP-4400 Portable Clamp-on Ultrasonic Flow Meter.

ONICON's FP-4400 Portable Clamp-on Ultrasonic Flow Meter utilizes clamp-on
transducers to measure flow through the pipe wall via the transit time ultrasonic
measurement principle. It is a battery operated flow meter specifically designed
for use on a wide range of pipe sizes and can provide a full day of use on a
single charge (an AC adapter is also provided for longer flow testing). The clamp
on design does NOT require a system shutdown or penetration of the pipe in any way
when installing and operating this meter. Instead, precision matched signal transducers
are mounted on the pipe to accurately measure flow through the pipe wall. The rugged,
handheld backlit display allows for easy set up via intuitive menus.

The FP-4400 portable clamp-on ultrasonic flow meter is ideal for flow testing
during test and balance. It is also useful for temporary flow monitoring in
existing systems to establish baseline demand data.

OniconF1500FlowMeter.doc:
F-1500 Insertion Turbine Flow Meter for Steam.

F-1500 Series Insertion Turbine Flow Meters are designed for accurate,
cost-effective mass flow measurement of steam, high temperature liquids
and gases. Insertion turbine flow meters are ideal for use in larger steam
lines where downsizing the line size to improve flow measurement is not desirable.
In these applications, the pitch of the turbine rotor is selected to match
the expected steam flow velocity range in the pipe. This optimizes the
operating range of the flow meter for the application.  The standard loop
powered version of the meter is equipped with the internal temperature
compensation required for direct mass flow measurement of saturated steam.
Each F-1500 Flow Meter is provided with a 4-20mA analog output for flow rate,
a pulse output for totalization and a built-in user interface and display.
The standard loop powered meter also includes HART.

DateTime.doc: ISO 8601 timestamp followed by timezone identifier

Seq.doc: Sequence is base type for all collections

List.doc: Ordered list of zero or more values

Or type is a choice between one of multiple types.
It is a union of the set of types.

And.doc:
And type is a combination of multiple types.
It is an intersection of the set of types.

LibDependVersions.doc:
Version constraints for a library dependency.

The format is:
  <versions>  :=  <wildcard> | <range>
  <wildcard>  :=  <seg> "." <seg> "." <seg>
  <range>     :=  <wildcard> "-" <wildcard>
  <seg>       :=  <digits> | "x"

Examples:
  1.5.20           // match only 1.5.20
  1.5.x            // match any patch version within 1.5
  3.x.x            // match any version with 3 as major version
  1.5.20 - 1.x.x   // greater than 1.5.20 and has 1 in major ver

Resource.doc:
Resource is the base type supporting files.  All
resources reference a file via the uri tag.  Resources
support two taxonomies: one for media type (data, doc, image,
video, etc) and one for purpose (training, install guide, etc).

uri.doc:
URI of the resource file.  This should reference a URL on the
web via https.  Of if the resource is packaged into the xetolib
zip itself it should be a relative path such as "res/guide-spec.pdf".

Entity.doc:
Top-level dicts with a unique identifier.
See `docHaystack::Ontology#entities` chapter.

Actuator.doc:
Equipment to move or control a mechanism.  Actuators may be manually
operated or automated via a control system to convert an energy source
into mechanical energy.  Typically the energy source is electricity,
hydraulics, or pneumatics.

Ahu.doc:
Air Handling Unit: An enclosure with a fan that delivers air to a space
via ductwork and performs one or more of the functions of cleaning,
heating, cooling, humidifying, dehumidifying, ventilating or circulating
the air.  See `docHaystack::AHUs` chapter.

AirConditioningSystem.doc:
System for air treatment to control its temperature, humidity, cleanliness,
and distribution to meet the requirements of a conditioned space.

AirExhaustSystem.doc:
System consisting of one or more fans that remove air from the building.
Exhaust systems allow outdoor air to enter by ventilation inlets or normal
leakage paths sthrough the building envelope.

AirSystem.doc: System for moving air to maintain indoor thermal comfort and/or air quality.

AirVentilationSystem.doc:
System that supplies or removes air by natural or mechanical means to or
from any space in order to provide outdoor air to the space. Such air may or
may not have been conditioned.

AirHandlingEquip.doc:
HVAC equipment that conditions and delivers air via one or more fans.
Conditioning of air includes heating, cooling, humidification,
dehumidification, and ventilation. See `docHaystack::AHUs` chapter.

AirQualityZonePoints.doc:
Entity with logical grouping of zone air quality points.
See `docHaystack::Zones#airQuality` chapter.

AirTerminalUnit.doc:
Equipment in air distribution systems which terminate at the space.
Terminal units receive air from `airHandlingEquip` which have the
primarily responsibility to condition air.  Terminal units are primarily
responsible for delivery of air to the space and tempering the temperature.

Assembly.doc: A collection of manufactured parts or subassemblies.

Ates.doc:
Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage system.
See `docHaystack::ATES` chapter.

Battery.doc: Equipment used to store electric energy

Boiler.doc: Equipment to generate hot water or steam for heating

BranchSelector.doc:
Branch selector used for heat recovery in a VRF system.  These are
control devices directing the liquid refrigerant or gas refrigerant
to zones requiring cooling or heating. See `docHaystack::VRF#branchSelector`
chapter.

Cable.doc: An assembly of one or more insulated conductors.

Cav.doc:
Constant air volume terminal unit.  CAV systems use a constant
air flow rate with a variable air temperature.

ChilledWaterPlant.doc:
Plant used to generate chilled water for cooling.
See `docHaystack::Plants`.

ChilledWaterSystem.doc:
System that circulates water in its liquid state below ambient temperature
for cooling a space or process.

ChilledBeam.doc: Conditions a space using a heat exchanger integrated into the ceiling

Chiller.doc:
Equipment to remove heat from a liquid.  Chillers typically use a vapor
compression or an absorption refrigeration cycle.

Circuit.doc:
Electrical circuit and its associated components such as breakers.
See `docHaystack::ElecPanels#circuits` chapter.

Coil.doc:
Heat exchanger used to heat or cool air.  Coils are sub-components
of HVAC equipment such as `airHandlingEquip`.

CondenserWaterSystem.doc:
System that circulates water in its liquid state for rejecting heat
from a space or process.

Conduit.doc: Duct, pipe, or cable to convey a substance or phenomenon

Controller.doc:
Microprocessor based device used in a control system.  Controllers
interact with the physical world through direct I/O to sensors and
actuators or via network [protocols]`protocol`.

ControlsPanel.doc: Panel housing controllers and networking gear

CoolingTower.doc: Equipment to transfer waste heat into the atmosphere

Crac.doc:
Computer Room Air Conditioner: An FCU designed to condition a computer
room.  See `docHaystack::AHUs` and `docHaystack::DataCenters` chapters.

CurPoint.doc:
Point with support to report a "real-time" current value.  By real-time
we typically mean freshness within the order of a few seconds or at
most a few minutes.  For systems with direct I/O the current value is
typically driven by the I/O scan rate. For overlay systems which acquire
data via a protocol such as BACnet or Modbus then the current value
is typically refreshed using polling or subscription over a network.
Also see `docHaystack::Points#cur` chapter.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

DamperActuator.doc: Actuator to regulate the flow of air.

DataCenter.doc:
Space used to house computer and networking gear.
See `docHaystack::DataCenters` chapter.

Device.doc:
Microprocessor based hardware device.  This is the general term for
all computers, mobile phones, controllers, and I/O modules.
See `docHaystack::Devices#networks` chapter.

Doas.doc:
Dedicated Outside Air System: An AHU that brings in 100% outside air and
no recirculated air in order to provide ventilation to spaces.
See `docHaystack::AHUs` chapter.

DomesticColdWaterSystem.doc:
System that circulates potable cold water in its liquid state for purposes
other than space cooling and process requirements.

DomesticHotWaterSystem.doc:
System that circulates potable hot water in its liquid state for purposes
other than space heating and process requirements.

DomesticWaterSystem.doc:
System that circulates potable water in its liquid state for purposes
other than space conditioning and process requirements.

Duct.doc: Conduit used to convey air for HVAC

ElecPanel.doc:
Physical housing for electrical circuits, fuses, and breakers.
See `docHaystack::ElecPanels#panels` chapter.

ElecSystem.doc: System that generates, converts, distributes, and/or stores electricity.

Elevator.doc: Enclosure used to move people between floors.

Escalator.doc: Moving staircase used to move people between floors.

EvseAssembly.doc:
Equipment that delivers electricity via EVSE ports to charging inlets
located on EVs.  See `docHaystack::EVSE#assembly` chapter.

EvseCable.doc:
Models the electrical connection between an `evse-port` and an EV charging
inlet.  See `docHaystack::EVSE#cable` chapter.

EvseEquip.doc:
Equipment that supports the delivery of electricity to charging inlets
located on EVs.  See `docHaystack::EVSE` chapter.

EvsePort.doc:
An EVSE port delivers electricity to a single EV charging inlet at a
time.  See `docHaystack::EVSE#port` chapter.

EvseSystem.doc:
A system that supplies electricity to EVSE assembly equipment and its
auxiliary loads.

FanMotor.doc:
Motor used with a fan to create air flow.
See `docHaystack::Motors` chapter.

Fcu.doc:
Fan Coil Unit: A unitary, factory-made enclosure with a fan and coil
that recirculates air in a space and performs one or more of the
functions of cleaning, heating, cooling, humidifying, dehumidifying,
or ventilating the air. Unit heaters are examples of FCUs.
See `docHaystack::AHUs` chapter.

Floor.doc: Storey of a building.  See `docHaystack::Spaces#floors` chapter.

FlowMeter.doc:
Meter to measure flow rate and total volume of fluid.
See `docHaystack::Meters` chapter.

FlowInverter.doc: System to change direction of substance flow

FumeHood.doc: Ventilation equipment to limit exposure to hazardous fumes.

GroundFloor.doc:
Floor at ground level.  In North America this is typically called
the first floor, but in Europe its often labeled as floor zero.
If `floorNum` is defined, then it must be set to zero.

HeatExchanger.doc: Equipment to transfer heat between two working fluids.

HisPoint.doc:
Historized point with a history log of timestamp/value pairs.  Points
marked as historized indicate the system can response to queries via
the 'hisRead' operation to return a trend log of timestamp/value pairs.

There are typically two mechanisms for historization:
  - the local system performs the historization by logging the
    point's `curVal` to local storage
  - in overlay systems a downstream device performs the historization
    and the local system synchronizes the history data in batch on
    a periodic basis

Also see `docHaystack::Points#his` chapter.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

HotWaterPlant.doc:
Plant used to generate hot water for heating.
See `docHaystack::Plants`.

HotWaterSystem.doc:
System that circulates water in its liquid state for heating
a space or process.

HumidifierEquip.doc: Equipment which adds moisture to air to increase humidity

HvacZoneSpace.doc:
Zone related to conditioning of a space's air temperature and quality.
See `docHaystack::Spaces#zones` and `docHaystack::Zones#hvac` chapters.

HvacZonePoints.doc:
Entity with logical grouping of zone HVAC air points.
See `docHaystack::Zones#hvac` chapter.

LightingZoneSpace.doc:
Zone related to lighting system.
See `docHaystack::Spaces#zones` and `docHaystack::Zones#lighting` chapters.

LightingZonePoints.doc:
Entity with logical grouping of lighting points.
See `docHaystack::Zones#lighting` chapter.

Luminaire.doc: Light fixture using electricity to provide illumination

Mau.doc:
Makeup Air Unit: A DOAS that provides make-up air for a separate, dedicated
exhaust system. That is, this equip does not contain an exhaust air section.
See `docHaystack::AHUs` chapter.

Meter.doc:
Equipment to meter a substance or phenomenon.
See `docHaystack::Meters` chapter.

MobilePhone.doc: Cellular phone providing telecommunication over radio links.

Motor.doc:
Equipment that converts electrical energy into mechanical energy.
See `docHaystack::Motors` chapter.

MovingWalkway.doc: Conveyor to move people across a horizontal or inclined plane.

Network.doc:
Logical communications network between two or more devices.
See `docHaystack::Devices#networks` chapter.

NetworkingDevice.doc: Microprocessor device used to establish networks.

NetworkingRouter.doc: Networking device used to route data between different networks.

NetworkingSwitch.doc: Networking device used to connect devices on the same network.

Panel.doc:
Enclosure for electrical and control equipment.  Panels may be
used to isolate electrical connections and provide environmental
protection.

Pipe.doc: Conduit used to convey a fluid

Plant.doc:
Central plant used to generate a substance for a process.
See `docHaystack::Plants`.

Point.doc:
Data point such as a sensor or actuator.
See `docHaystack::Points` chapter.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

PointGroup.doc: Grouping of children points used by spaces and equipment

PumpMotor.doc:
Motor used with a pump to move fluid.
See `docHaystack::Motors` chapter.

Rack.doc:
Enclosure or chassis used to mount computer and networking gear.
Devices are mounted to rails of a standard width, typically 19 or 23
inches.  Height is measured in *rack units* where one 1U is 1.75 inches.
A full rack has a height of 42U.
See `docHaystack::DataCenters#racks` chapter.

RadiantEquip.doc: HVAC equipment that conditions a space without forced air.

RadiantFloor.doc: Heats a space using pipes or cables embedded beneath floor.

Radiator.doc:
Heats a space using exposed pipes or coils.  Hot water and steam
radiators are often cast iron and installed directly in the space
or along the baseboard.  Electric radiators are typically installed
on the baseboard.

RefrigSystem.doc: Refrigerant distribution to fulfill all or parts of a refrigeration cycle.

RoofFloor.doc:
The roof floor is the topmost level of a building.  It is often
where HVAC equipment is located such as rooftop AHUs.

Rtu.doc:
Roof Top Unit: A unitary AHU that is weatherized for outdoor use.
See `docHaystack::AHUs` chapter.

ServerComputer.doc: General purpose computer used as a server.  Typically servers are rack mounted.

Site.doc:
Site is a geographic location of the built environment.
Typically site maps to one building with its own unique
street address.  See `docHaystack::Sites` chapter.

Space.doc:
Space is a three-dimensional volume in the built environment.
See `docHaystack::Spaces` chapter.

SteamPlant.doc:
Plant used to generate steam for heating.
See `docHaystack::Plants`.

SteamSystem.doc:
System that circulates water in its vapor state for heating
a space or process.

SubterraneanFloor.doc:
Floor below ground level.  Subterranean floors are also known as
basements, lower levels, or cellars.

System.doc:
Grouping of related equipment dedicated to a single application.
See `docHaystack::Systems` chapter.

Tablet.doc: Mobile device with touch screen for user input.

Tank.doc: Tank used to store a substance for temporary holding

Thermostat.doc:
Senses and controls temperature of space in HVAC system.  Thermostats
may provide an interface for setpoint control.

UnitVent.doc:
Unit Ventilator: An FCU that has direct access to outside air to provide
the space with ventilation.  See `docHaystack::AHUs` chapter.

ValveActuator.doc: Actuator to regulate the flow of fluid.

Vav.doc:
Variable air volume terminal unit.  VAV systems use a constant air
temperature with a variable air flow rate.  See `docHaystack::VAVs` chapter.

VerticalTransport.doc: Equipment to move humans and materials

VrfCoolingOnlySystem.doc:
Cooling only VRF system can only cool; heating is not available.
See `docHaystack::VRF#types` chapter.

VrfEquip.doc: Equipment used in VRF systems.  See `docHaystack::VRF#equip` chapter.

VrfHeatPumpSystem.doc:
Heat pump VRF system can either heat, or cool, but not at the same time.
See `docHaystack::VRF#types` chapter.

VrfHeatRecoverySystem.doc:
Heat recovery VRF system can operate cooling and heating by each indoor unit
independently, at the same time. Heat recovery VRF systems have branch selectors
to control how much, and which (hot gas or subcooled liquid) refrigerant
goes to each indoor unit.  See `docHaystack::VRF#types` chapter.

VrfIndoorUnit.doc:
Indoor unit in a VRF system.  Indoor units operate to satisfy a heating
or cooling load. See `docHaystack::VRF#indoorUnits` chapter.

VrfIndoorUnitFcu.doc:
Indoor unit fan coil unit in a VRF system.  This includes but is not
limited to: ducted-type and non-ducted types such as wall-mount,
floor-mount, ceiling-mount and cassettes.  Indoor unit fan coils operate
to satisfy a heating  or cooling load in a zone based on a zone thermostat
temperature set point.

VrfOutdoorUnit.doc:
Outdoor unit with one or more compressors in a VRF system. As each indoor
unit sends a demand to the outdoor unit, outdoor unit delivers the amount
of refrigerant needed to meet the individual requirements of each indoor
unit.  See `docHaystack::VRF#outdoorUnits` chapter.

VrfRefrigPlant.doc: Group of outdoor units in a VRF system.  See `docHaystack::VRF#refrigPlant`.

VrfSystem.doc:
Variable refigerant flow system.  The system contains the indoor
units, outdoor units, and branch selectors.  See `docHaystack::VRF#types`
chapter.

WaterSystem.doc: System that supplies or collects potable or non-potable water in any state.

WeatherPoint.doc:
Weather station observation point.
See `docHaystack::Weather#points` chapter.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

WeatherStation.doc:
Logical weather station and its measurement points.
See `docHaystack::Weather#stations` chapter.

Well.doc:
A well is a source of groundwater and potentially thermal energy.  When
used within an [ATES]`docHaystack::ATES` system, the well facilitates thermal
energy exchange with the ground warm and cool water sources. In this case, a
well can be either a closed system that transports water through pipes in the
ground, or an open system that pumps up and returns ground water.

Wire.doc: Cabling used to convey electricity or data

WritablePoint.doc:
Point with writable output using 16-level priority array.  Writable
points typically are a setpoint or actuator command.  Haystack writable
points are modeled on the BACnet 16-level priority array with a
relinquish default which effectively acts as level 17.

The following levels have special behavior:
 - **Level 1**: highest priority reserved for emergency overrides
 - **Level 8**: manual override with ability to set timer to expire back to auto
 - **Default**: implicitly acts as level 17 for relinquish default

The priority array provides for contention resolution when many different
control applications may be vying for control of a given point. Low level
applications like scheduling typically control levels 14, 15, or 16. Then
users can override at level 8. But a higher levels like 2 to 7 can be used
to trump a user override (for example a demand response energy routine
that requires higher priority).

The actual value to write is resolved by starting at level 1 and working down
to relinquish default to find the first non-null value. It is possible for
all levels to be null, in which case the overall write output is null (which
in turn may be auto/null to another system). Anytime a null value is written
to a priority level, we say that level has been set to auto or released (this
allows the next highest level to take command of the output).

Also see `docHaystack::Points#writable` chapter.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

ZoneSpace.doc:
Space associated with a specific system.
See `docHaystack::Spaces#zones` and `docHaystack::Zones` chapters.

Symbol.doc:
Symbol to a def. Symbol values are ASCII strings limited to the
following chars: a-z, A-Z, 0-9, underbar, colon, dash, dot.

Coord.doc: Geographic coordinate in latitude/longitude in decimal degrees.

XStr.doc: Extended string - type name and string value encoding.

Grid.doc: Two dimension table of columns and rows.

CB.doc:
A circuit breaker is an automatically operated electrical switch designed to
protect an electrical circuit from damage caused by excess current from an overload
or short circuit.

UPS.doc:
An electrical apparatus that provides emergency power to a load when the input
power source or mains power fails.

ACR.doc: Uses air to cool hot refrigerant.

CHWDC.doc: Chilled water valve control on discharge air side.

CHWZC.doc: Chilled water valve control on zone side.

CWLC.doc: Condenser water valve control on leaving side.

DD.doc: The base function of a dual duct equipment

DFSS.doc: Combination of discharge fan run command and status (start/stop).

DFVDC.doc: Variable speed control for discharge fans.

DXZC.doc: Compressor run control on zone side.

DXDC.doc: Compressor run control on discharge side.

EFSS.doc: Combination of exhaust fan run command and status (start/stop).

EFVSC.doc: Variable speed control for exhaust fans.

HPZC.doc: Heat Pump run control on zone side.

HTEZC.doc: Electric heater control on zone side (ZC).

HTGZC.doc: Gas heater control on zone side (ZC).

HWZC.doc: Heating water valve monitoring on zone side

PDZC.doc: Pressure dependent single cooling setpoint control.

PHWSC.doc: Hot water preheat valve control on supply air side.

HWDC.doc: Hot water valve control on discharge air side.

SD.doc: The base function of a single duct equipment

SID.doc: The base function of a single inlet duct equipment

WCR.doc:
Uses water to cool hot refrigerant (or heat cold refrigerant), basically a refrigerant
to condenser water heat exchange process.

VRFOUREF.doc: VRF Refrigeration Control and Monitoring for Outdoor Units

VRFOUAIR.doc: VRF Control and Monitoring for Air-Cooled Outdoor Units

VRFOUWTR.doc: VRF Control and Monitoring for Water-Cooled Outdoor Units

ATS.doc: A transfer switch is an electrical switch that switches a load between two sources.

CIR.doc:
A circuit or electrical circuit supplies electricity to an area or sub-system
within a building.

EDP.doc:
An electrical distribution panel or electrical panel is a central part of the
electrical supply system in a building that divides an electrical power feed
into subsidiary circuits

ESB.doc:
A component of an electricity supply system that directs electricity from one
or more sources of supply to several smaller regions of usage.

COGEN.doc:
A Cogenerator is a combined heat and power (CHP) system that contains an electrical
generator and a heat recovery system that provides hot water that can be utilized
by the building.

GEN.doc:
An Electric Generator is a component of an electricity supply system that converts
motive power (mechanical energy) into electrical power for use in an external
circuit.

HVDP.doc:
A high voltage distribution panel is a component of an electricity supply system
that divides an electrical power feed into subsidiary circuits, while providing
a protective fuse or circuit breaker for each circuit in a common enclosure.

HVSB.doc:
A High Voltage Switchboard is a component of an electricity supply system that
directs electricity from one or more sources of supply to several smaller regions
of usage.

IPS.doc:
Integrated Power switchboards combine circuit breakers, chassis, and transformers,
as well as other electrical products.

LI.doc:
Lighting inverters maintain crucial AC Power to operate all emergency lighting
at “full light” output, providing superior dependability and security to any
office, commercial or industrial environment.

LVDP.doc:
A low voltage  distribution panel is a component of an electricity supply system
that divides an electrical power feed into subsidiary circuits, while providing
a protective fuse or circuit breaker for each circuit in a common enclosure.

LVSB.doc:
A Low Voltage Switchboard is a component of an electricity supply system that
directs electricity from one or more sources of supply to several smaller regions
of usage.

MDU.doc:
A mains distribution unit (MDU) is a device fitted with multiple outputs designed
to distribute electric power, especially to racks of computers and networking
equipment located within a data center.

MSB.doc:
A Mains Switchboard  is a component of an electricity supply system that directs
electricity from one or more sources of supply to several smaller regions of
usage.

PDU.doc:
A power distribution unit (PDU) is a device fitted with multiple outputs designed
to distribute electric power, especially to racks of computers and networking
equipment located within a data center.

SCS.doc:
A sectionalizer is a protective device that automatically isolates a faulted
section of line from the rest of the distribution system.

SSTN.doc:
Substations transform voltage from high to low, or the reverse, or perform any
of several other important functions.

SWGR.doc:
In an electric power system, switchgear is composed of electrical disconnect
switches, fuses or circuit breakers used to control, protect and isolate electrical
equipment.

XFMR.doc:
In an electric power system, a passive electrical device that transfers electrical
energy from one electrical circuit to another in order to increase or decrease
the voltage.

COIL.doc: Heat exchanger used to heat or cool air

DXCOIL.doc: A DX Coil uses direct-expansion of refrigerants for heating and cooling.

HX.doc:
A heat exchanger is a system used to transfer heat between two or more fluids.
Heat exchangers are used in both cooling and heating processes.

RADF.doc: Heats a space using pipes or cables embedded beneath floor.

RADFE.doc: Heats a space using pipes or cables embedded beneath floor.

DLTLVLSP.doc: The light level setpoint in percent when daylighting is enabled.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

EFLTLVLSP.doc: The light level setpoint in percent.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

ENDLC.doc: Enable daylighting control of light levels.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

LDSHLTLVLSP.doc: The light level reduction in percent when loadshedding is active.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point
Parent equips that contain this point

LTCLRT.doc: The color temperature of the light.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point
Parent equips that contain this point

LTLVL.doc: A measure of the light level in percent.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

LTLVLCMD.doc: Dimming control of a light or group of lights in a lighting zone.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

LTOCMODE.doc: The occupancy control mode for a lighting group or zone.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

LTPC.doc: A measure of the illuminance in footcandles.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point
Parent equips that contain this point
Parent equips that contain this point

OCLTLVLSP.doc: The light level setpoint in percent during the occupied period.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

OLTPC.doc: A measure of the outdoor ambient illuminance in footcandle.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

UOCLTLVLSP.doc: The light level setpoint in percent during the unoccupied period.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

SHPOS.doc: The vertical position of the shades.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point
Parent equips that contain this point

SHDIR.doc: The direction the shades are moving, opening, closing or stopped.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

SHPOSCMD.doc: Extent control of a shade or group of shades in a group.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

SHTLTCMD.doc: Tilt control of a shade or group of shades in a group.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

CAM.doc: A camera is an optical instrument used to record images.

CNTRL.doc: A microprocessor Controller on any type of equipment

DWB.doc:
Digital whiteboards replace traditional dry-erase boards in hospital patient
rooms. With information that is up-to-the-minute accurate, the patients, their
families and staff can benefit from knowing their pain-level, mobility status,
fall risk, plan for the day, etc.

ETP.doc: A port is a communication endpoint.

HMI.doc:
An human-machine interface (HMI) that interfaces machines with physical input
hardware such as keyboards, mice, game pads and output hardware such as computer
monitors, speakers, and printers.

POEETP.doc: A PoE port is a communication endpoint that supplies DC Power to the endpoint.

PTZCAM.doc: A camera is an optical instrument used to record images.

device.doc: Marker labels a dict with typing information

SAN.doc:
A storage area network (SAN) or storage network is a computer network which provides
access to consolidated, block-level data storage.

SDNC.doc:
The SDN Controller is a logically centralized entity in charge of translating
the requirements from the SDN Application layer down to the SDN Datapaths and
providing the SDN Applications with an abstract view of the network.

SUPC.doc:
A microprocessor Controller whose primary function is to integrate and supervise
other controllers

RACK.doc: Enclosure or chassis used to mount computer and networking gear

CHBZC.doc: Chilled Beam with Chilled Water Cooling and Hot water Heating (zone control)

LOCM.doc: Line, Entry or In/Out Occupancy Monitoring

ACT.doc:
An actuator is a device that is responsible for moving and controlling a mechanism
or system, for example by opening a valve.

VAP.doc: A vaporizer or vaporiser is a device used to vaporize substances for inhalation.

VFD.doc: Device that varies the frequency output to a motor

WDO.doc: A device that provides the means to open and close a window to allow ventilation

ROOM.doc: A generic enclosed space within a building

BREAKRM.doc:
A room set aside to use during a break from work for the purpose of relaxing,
socializing or eating.

CIRCULATION.doc: A space used by people to move throughout a building - hallways, stair.

CONRM.doc: A room provided for singular events such as business conferences and meetings.

DATAHALL.doc: A room used for storing servers, storage, and communication equipment in a facility.

EDRM.doc: A room for providing or gaining knowledge

FTNSRM.doc: A general class of space types used for sports, working out and exercise

HEALTHCARERM.doc:
A class for rooms for the maintaining and restoration of health by the treatment
and prevention of disease.

LABROOM.doc: A room used for research within a facility

LOBBY.doc: An entranceway or foyer in a building

LCKRROOM.doc:
A room containing lockers for the storage of personal belongings and typically
bathing and restroom facilities, especially in schools or gymnasiums.

PERHYGIENE.doc:
A general class of space types used to maintain cleanliness of one's body and
clothing to preserve overall health and well-being.

RESIDENCE.doc:
An individual space (Dormitory Room) or collection of rooms(Bedroom, Living Room,
etc) providing sleeping and living quarters.

RETAILRM.doc: A general class of space types used for the sale of goods to the public

STRGRM.doc: A room for holding goods or supplies for future use.

UTILRM.doc: A room not intended for prolonged human occupancy or material storage.

CLASSRM.doc: A room for formal instructor led learning.

DORMRM.doc: A room providing sleeping and residential quarters for students at a school.

ELECRM.doc:
A room or space dedicated to the electrical equipment for managing power distribution.
not intended for prolonged human occupancy or material storage.

MECHRM.doc:
A room or space dedicated to the equipment for managing environmental quality,
lighting and life safety equipment, not intended for prolonged human occupancy
or material storage.

MORTUARY.doc:
A room where dead bodies are kept in preparation for burial or cremation, or
in the case of a hospital or school, for study and examination.

RESTROOM.doc: A room in a public space providing toilets and lavatories, a public bathroom

SRVROOM.doc:
Space used to house computer and networking gear. Includes MDF (Main Distribution
Frame), IDF(Intermediate Distribution Frame), Telecom Rooms, and IT Closets.

STUDYRM.doc: A room for small group or self-directed study.

PRKG.doc: Parking lot gates provide security and control for parking lots and parking garages.

WM.doc:
A water meter is a device that measures the amount of water consumed by a residence,
a business or equipment.

EM.doc:
An electricity meter, electric meter, electrical meter, or energy meter is a
device that measures the amount of electric energy consumed by a residence, a
business, or an electrically powered device.

NGM.doc:
A natural gas meter is a device that measures the amount of natural gas consumed
by a residence, a business or equipment.

HM.doc:
A heat meter, or thermal meter, is a device that measures the amount of heat
energy consumed.

SM.doc: A steam meter is a device that measures the flow rate of steam.

CHWM.doc:
A chilled water meter is a device that measures the amount of chilled water delivered
to a piece of HVAC equipment.

HWM.doc:
A hot water meter is a device that measures the amount of heating hot water delivered
to a piece of HVAC equipment.

CWM.doc:
A condenser water meter is a device that measures the amount of condenser water
delivered to a piece of HVAC equipment.

DWM.doc:
A domestic cold water meter is a device that measures the amount of domestic
(cold) water consumed by a residence, a business or equipment.

DHWM.doc:
A domestic hot water meter is a device that measures the amount of domestic hot
water consumed by a residence, a business or equipment.

BDWM.doc:
A wastewater meter is a device that measures the amount of wastewater generated
by a residence, a business, process or equipment.

MUWM.doc:
A makeup water meter is a device that measures the amount of makeup water (typically
domestic water) consumed by an equipment or hydronic system.

WWM.doc:
A wastewater meter is a device that measures the amount of wastewater generated
by a residence, a business, process or equipment.

FP.doc:
A fire pump increases pressure as part of a fire sprinkler system's water supply.
The pump provides water flow at a higher pressure to the sprinkler system risers
and hose standpipes.

FSUP.doc:
Fire suppression systems are used to extinguish or prevent the spread of fire
in a building.

AW.doc:
An Autowalk is a moving walkway that transports people across a horizontal or
inclined plane over a short to medium distance.

ELV.doc:
An elevator (US and Canada) or lift (UK, Ireland and Australia) is a type of
vertical transportation machine that moves people or freight between floors,
levels, or decks of a building, vessel, or other structure.

ELVGRP.doc: A set of elevators that are grouped under the same controller.

ELVLND.doc: A floor stop for an elevator (or lift).

ESC.doc: An escalator is a moving staircase which carries people between floors of a building.

SITE.doc:
A geographic location of the built environment. Typically site maps to one building
with its own unique street address.

BANKBR.doc:
Bank Branch refers to a commercial banking outlet that offers banking services
to walk-in customers.

CASINO.doc:
Casino refers to buildings primarily used to conduct gambling activities including
both electronic and live table games.

COURT.doc:
Courthouse refers to buildings used for federal, state, or local courts, and
associated administrative office space.

DATACTR.doc:
Data Center refers to buildings specifically designed and equipped to meet the
needs of high density computing equipment, such as server racks, used for data
storage and processing.

DISTCTR.doc:
Distribution Center refers to unrefrigerated buildings that are used for the
temporary storage and redistribution of goods, manufactured products, merchandise
or raw materials. Buildings that are used primarily for assembling, modifying,
manufacturing, or growing goods, products, merchandise or raw material should
be classified as Manufacturing Facility.

DWTRTRT.doc:
Drinking Water Treatment and Distribution refers to facilities designed to pump
and distribute drinking water through a network of pipes. Depending on the water
source (ground water, surface water, purchased water), a water utility may or
may not contain a treatment process. This property use applies to any/all water
sources and any/all levels of treatment.

ENERPWR.doc:
Energy/Power Station applies to buildings containing machinery and/or associated
equipment for generating electricity or district heat (steam, hot water, or chilled
water) from a raw fuel, including fossil fuel power plants, traditional district
heat power plants, combined heat and power plants, nuclear reactors, hydroelectric
dams, or facilities associated with a solar or wind farm.

FSTFOOD.doc:
Fast Food Restaurant, also known as Quick Service Restaurant, refers to buildings
used for the preparation and sale of ready-to-eat food. Fast Food Restaurants
are characterized by a limited menu of food prepared quickly (often within a
few minutes), and sometimes cooked in bulk in advance and kept hot.

FIRE.doc:
Fire Station refers to buildings used to provide emergency response services
associated with fires. Fire stations may be staffed by either volunteer or full-time
paid firefighters.

FITNESS.doc:
Fitness Center/Health Club/Gym refers to buildings used for recreational or professional
athletic training and related activities.

HOSP.doc:
Hospital refers to a general medical and surgical hospital (including critical
access hospitals and children’s hospitals).

HOTEL.doc:
Hotel refers to buildings renting overnight accommodations on a room/suite and
nightly basis, and typically include a bath/shower and other facilities in guest
rooms. Hotel properties typically have daily services available to guests including
housekeeping/laundry and a front desk/concierge.

K12.doc:
K-12 School refers to buildings or campuses used as a school for Kindergarten
through 12th grade students.

LAB.doc:
Laboratory refers to buildings that provide controlled conditions in which scientific
research, measurement, and experiments are performed or practical science is
taught.

LIBRARY.doc:
Library refers to buildings used to store and manage collections of literary
and artistic materials such as books, periodicals, newspapers, films, etc. that
can be used for reference or lending.

MALL.doc:
Enclosed Mall refers to buildings that house multiple stores, often “anchored”
by one or more department stores, and with interior walkways. Most stores will
not have entrances accessible from outside, with the exception of the “anchor”
stores.

MIXUSE.doc:
A Mixed Use (or multi use) property is one contains multiple property types,
none of which are greater than 50% of the total Gross Floor Area (GFA), including
parking GFA.

MOB.doc:
Medical Office refers to buildings used to provide diagnosis and treatment for
medical, dental, or psychiatric outpatient care.

MOVIE.doc: Movie theater refers to buildings used for public or private film screenings.

MLTFAM.doc:
Multifamily Housing refers to residential properties that contain two or more
residential living units. These properties may include low-rise buildings (1-4
stories), mid-rise buildings (5-9 stories), or high-rise buildings (10+ stories).
Occupants of these buildings may include tenants, cooperators, and/or individual
owners.

MUSEUM.doc:
Museum refers to buildings that display collections to outside visitors for public
viewing and enjoyment and for informational/educational purposes.

OUTIL.doc:
Other - Utility applies to buildings used by a utility for some purpose other
than general office or energy/power generation. This may include utility transfer
stations, maintenance facilities and central plants for generating hot water,
chilled water, steam, etc.

OMALL.doc:
Other-Mall refers to buildings containing a collection of stores whose purpose
is the sale of goods, but which do not fit into the enclosed mall, lifestyle
center, or strip mall property types.

OPRP.doc:
Outpatient Rehabilitation/Physical Therapy offices refers to buildings used to
provide diagnosis and treatment for rehabilitation and physical therapy.

OSPCHOSP.doc:
Specialty Hospitals refers to long-term acute care hospitals, inpatient rehabilitation
facilities, including Cancer Centers and Psychiatric and Substance Abuse Hospitals/Facilities.

OFFICE.doc:
Office refers to buildings used to conduct commercial or governmental business
activities. This includes administrative and professional offices.

PARKING.doc: Parking refers to buildings and lots used for parking vehicles.

PERF.doc:
Performing Arts refers to buildings used for public or private artistic or musical
performances.

POLICE.doc:
Police Station applies to buildings used for federal, state, or local police
forces and their associated office space.

DORM.doc:
Residence Hall/Dormitory refers to buildings associated with educational institutions
or military facilities which offer multiple accommodations for long-term residents.

REST.doc:
Restaurant refers to buildings used for preparation and sale of ready-to-eat
food and beverages, but which do not fit in the fast food property type. Examples
include fast casual, casual, and fine dining restaurants.

RETST.doc:
Retail Store refers to individual stores used to conduct the retail sale of non-food
consumer goods such as Department Stores, Discount Stores, Drug Stores, Dollar
Stores, Hardware Stores, and Apparel/Specialty Stores (e.g. books, clothing,
office products, sporting goods, toys, home goods, and electronics). Buildings
containing multiple stores should be classified as enclosed mall, lifestyle center,
or strip mall.

SENIORLV.doc:
Senior Living Community refers to buildings that house and provide care and assistance
for elderly residents, specifically homes (skilled nursing facilities) and assisted
living facilities. It is NOT intended for retirement or other senior communities
that offer only independent living – a community with only independent living
should benchmark as a Multifamily property (see below for further details).

SUPERMKT.doc:
Supermarket/Grocery Store refers to buildings used for the retail sale of primarily
food and beverage products, and which may include small amounts of preparation
and sale of ready-to-eat food. Buildings where the primary business is the onsite
preparation and sale of ready-to-eat food should use one of the Restaurant property
types.

STRMALL.doc:
Strip mall refers to buildings comprising more than one retail store, restaurant,
or other business, in an open-air configuration where each establishment has
an exterior entrance to the public and there are no internal walkways.

UNIV.doc:
College/University refers to buildings used for the purpose of higher education.
This includes public and private colleges and universities.

URGCLIN.doc:
Urgent Care Center/Clinic/Other Outpatient Office refers to buildings used to
treat patients, usually on an unscheduled, walk-in basis, who have an injury
or illness that requires immediate care but is not serious enough to warrant
a visit to an emergency department.

WASTEWTR.doc: Wastewater Treatment Plant refers to facilities designed to treat municipal wastewater.

WORSHIP.doc:
Worship Facility refers to buildings that are used as places of worship. This
includes churches, temples, mosques, synagogues, meetinghouses, or any other
buildings that primarily function as a place of religious worship.

LVLLFLT.doc: Level has gone below a certain threshold and is generating a fault.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

LVLHFLT.doc: Level has gone above a certain threshold and is generating a fault.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

LKFLT.doc: Equipment is indicating a leak fault.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

JMFLT.doc: Equipment is indicating a jam or stuck in position fault.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

CHWC.doc:
Heat exchanger used to cool air using chilled water as the source. Coils are
sub-components of HVAC equipment such as airHandlingEquip.

CWCOIL.doc:
Heat exchanger used to heat or cool air using condenser water as the source.
Coils are sub-components of HVAC equipment such as airHandlingEquip.

HWC.doc:
Heat exchanger used to heat air using hot water as the source. Coils are sub-components
of HVAC equipment such as airHandlingEquip.

BLR.doc: A boiler is a closed vessel in which fluid (generally water) is heated.

HWB.doc: Simple hot water boiler with start/stop and leaving temperature control

HWBISOV.doc: Simple hot water boiler with leaving control and leaving isolation

SB.doc:
A steam boiler is a closed vessel in which fluid (generally water) is heated
to steam.

CSG.doc:
Clean steam generators are used to produce pure and clean steam, free of any
harmful substances and impurities. Applications include pharmacies and hospitals,
as well as food and cosmetic industries.

PUMP.doc:
Machine for imparting energy to a fluid, causing it to do work, drawing a fluid
into itself through an entrance port, and forcing the fluid out through an exhaust
port.

BCP.doc: A specific type of pump used to circulate water within a boiler.

BFWP.doc: A specific type of pump used to pump feedwater into a steam boiler.

PCHWP.doc: Pump that moves Chilled Water through chiller

SCHWP.doc: Pump that moves Chilled Water from a Chilled Water Plant to the load

TCHWP.doc: Pump that moves Chilled Water within the buildings to the load

CP.doc:
A circulator pump or circulating pump is a specific type of pump used to circulate
gases, liquids, or slurries in a closed circuit.

ENV.doc:
A pressure independent valve utilizing advanced cloud-based analytics to leverage
captured system data to its full potential providing savings and the most efficient
operation.

VLV.doc:
A valve is a device that regulates, directs or controls the flow of a fluid (gases,
liquids, fluidized solids, or slurries) by opening, closing, or partially obstructing
various passageways.

CH.doc:
A chiller is a machine that removes heat from a liquid via a vapor-compression
or absorption refrigeration cycle.

CHWPL.doc:
A chilled water plant containing equipment and piping to deliver chilled water
to a building, process, or equipment.

CHWHWPL.doc:
A chilled and heating hot water plant containing equipment and piping to deliver
both chilled and heating hot water to a building, process, or equipment.

CNR.doc:
A condensate receiver, also called a condensate tank, captures it and sends it
back to the boiler room so it can be reused.

CT.doc:
A cooling tower is a heat rejection device that rejects waste heat to the atmosphere
through the cooling of a water stream to a lower temperature.

CWPL.doc:
A condenser water plant containing equipment and piping to deliver condenser
water to a building, process, or equipment.

DEA.doc:
A deaerator reduces dissolved gases, particularly oxygen, to a low level and
improve a plant's thermal efficiency by raising the water temperature. In addition,
deaerators provide feedwater storage and proper suction conditions for boiler
feedwater pumps.

HWPL.doc:
A hot water plant contains equipment and piping to deliver hot water to a building,
process, or equipment.

HXW.doc: A water heat exchanger is an equip which transfers heat between two water flows.

LTCH.doc: Chillers that can cool process fluids in temperatures as low as -40°F

PRV.doc:
A PRV lowers the pressure for safety and efficiency, and to match the requirements
of the application.

SPL.doc:
A steam plant containing equipment and piping to deliver steam to a building,
process, or equipment.

SPRV.doc:
A PRV lowers the steam pressure for safety and efficiency, and to match the requirements
of the application.

TWHP.doc:
A hydronic heat pump,  also known as a "reversible chiller", is a machine that
removes heat from or adds heat to a liquid via vapor-compression or absorption
refrigeration cycle.

ATWHP.doc:
An air to water heat pump is a machine that removes heat from or adds heat to
a liquid via a vapor-compression or absorption refrigeration cycle that then
absorbs/rejects heat from the air. It is similar to an air-cooled chiller except
it can make hot water, chilled water, or sometimes both simultaneously.

WTWHP.doc:
A water to water heat pump is a machine that removes heat from or adds heat to
a liquid via a vapor-compression or absorption refrigeration cycle. It is similar
to an water-cooled chiller except it can make hot water, chilled water, or sometimes
both simultaneously.

ELVCALL.doc: List of calls for an Elevator.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point
Parent equips that contain this point

ASNLNDCALL.doc:
This property shall represent the current landing calls and their direction for
the lift represented by this object.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

CARDIRCMD.doc:
This represents the direction this elevator is assigned to move, based on current
car calls.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

CARDIR.doc:
This property represents whether or not this lift's car is moving, and if so,
in which direction.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

CARDRST.doc: This property indicates the status of the doors on the car.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

CARDRVST.doc: This property shall indicate the current status of the lift's motor drive system.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

CARLD.doc: This property indicates the load in the car, both passengers and goods.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

CARMD.doc: This property shall indicate the current operational mode of the car.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

CARNXTPOS.doc:
This property indicates the universal floor number where the car will stop next
when underway. If the car is not in motion, this property indicates the current
universal floor number.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

CARPOS.doc: This property indicates the universal floor number of this lift's car position.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

ELVOOS.doc:
This property is an indication whether (TRUE) or not (FALSE) the object is decoupled
from the lift that this object represents.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

ESCOOS.doc:
This property is an indication whether (TRUE) or not (FALSE) the object is decoupled
from the escalator that this object represents.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

MKCARCALL.doc: This indicates the last car calls written to this elevator.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

LNDCALL.doc: This contains all of the landing calls within an Elevator Group

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

LNDDRST.doc: This property indicates the status of the doors on the car.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

OPDIR.doc:
This property represents the direction and speed in which this escalator is presently
moving.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

PASALM.doc:
This property indicates whether (TRUE) or not (FALSE) the passenger alarm has
been activated.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

REGCARCALL.doc:
This property represents the lists of currently registered car calls (requests
to stop at particular floors using a particular door) for this lift.

equips.doc: Parent equips that contain this point

DHWST.doc: Equipment used to store domestic hot water.

DHWHT.doc: Equipment used to heat domestic hot water.

DHPWH.doc: Heat Pump Domestic Hot Water Heater

DHXWH.doc:
This is a water heater that uses hot water through a heat exchanger to heat domestic
hot water.

GI.doc:
A grease interceptor (also known as grease trap, grease recovery device, grease
capsule and grease converter) is a plumbing device (a type of trap) designed
to intercept most greases and solids before they enter a wastewater disposal
system.

INT.doc: Generic class of plumbing sanitary waste interceptor devices.

MDVCP.doc:
A medical vacuum pump is a medical grade device that removes gas molecules from
a sealed volume in order to leave behind a partial vacuum.

OI.doc:
An oil interceptor  is a plumbing device (a type of trap) designed to intercept
most oils before they enter a wastewater disposal system.

RWST.doc: Tank used to store collected rainwater.

RO.doc:
A system that removes contaminants from unfiltered water when pressure forces
it through a semi-permeable membrane.

SEP.doc:
A pump that is used to remove sewage that has collected in a basin. Similar to
a sump pump, but specifically for sanitary waste.

SMPP.doc: A pump used to remove water that has accumulated in a water-collecting sump basin

SOI.doc:
A sand oil interceptor  is a plumbing device (a type of trap) designed to intercept
most sand and oils before they enter a wastewater disposal system.

VCP.doc:
A vacuum pump is a device that removes gas molecules from a sealed volume in
order to leave behind a partial vacuum.

WSO.doc:
A device that removes calcium, magnesium, and certain other metal cations in
hard water.

DWS.doc:
A collection of entities related to the domestic water in a building such as
booster pumps, sensors, water treatment or softeners, or filtration. Domestic
water is also commonly called "Domestic Cold Water" or potable water. All elements
in the domestic water system should be interconnected thorough the domestic Water
distribution piping.

DHWS.doc:
A collection of entities related to the domestic hot water in a building such
as hot water heaters, tanks, recirculation pumps, sensors, water treatment or
softeners, or filtration. Domestic hot water is sometimes referred to as "hot
water", but it is distinct from "heating hot water" which is non-potable. All
elements in the domestic hot water system are interconnected through the domestic
Water distribution piping.

DHWPL.doc:
A domestic hot water plant contains equipment and piping that produces (heats)
domestic hot water for a building.

RWS.doc:
A collection of entities related to the rainwater collection (for purposes of
onsite reuse) in a building such as tanks, pumps, water treatment, or filtration.
All elements in the rainwater system are interconnected through the rainwater
or stormwater piping.

SANS.doc:
A collection of entities related to the disposal of sanitary wastewater in a
building. Sanitary water is sometimes called "sewage". All elements in the sanitary
waste system are interconnected through waste and vent piping.

STRMS.doc:
A collection of entities related to the disposal of onsite storm water on a site.
Stormwater is distinct from rainwater in that it is not intended for onsite reuse.
All elements in the stormwater system are interconnected through stormwater piping.

DTC.doc:
A desktop computer is a personal computer designed for regular use at a single
location on or near a desk or table due to its size and power requirements.

LTC.doc:
A laptop computer, often called a laptop or notebook, is a small, portable personal
computer with a "clamshell" form factor, typically having a thin LCD or LED computer
screen mounted on the inside of the upper lid of the clamshell and an alphanumeric
keyboard on the inside of the lower lid.

SRV.doc:
A computer program or a device that provides functionality for other programs
or devices, called "clients".

HUB.doc:
Network hardware device for connecting multiple devices together and making them
act as a single network segment

WLHUB.doc:
Network hardware device for connecting wireless multiple devices together and
making them act as a single network segment

ETS.doc:
Networking hardware that connects devices on a computer network by using packet
switching to receive and forward data to the destination device.

POEETS.doc:
An Ethernet Switch is networking hardware that connects devices on a computer
network by using packet switching to receive and forward data to the destination
device and is capable of supplying power via the Ethernet Ports.

FW.doc:
A firewall is a network security system that monitors and controls incoming and
outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules. A firewall typically
establishes a barrier between a trusted internal network and untrusted external
network, such as the Internet.

GW.doc: A device that connects 2 disparate networks.

LWGW.doc: A device that connects 2 disparate networks, one of which is LoRaWAN.

RTR.doc: A networking device that forwards data packets between computer networks.

WIFIRTR.doc:
A Wi-Fi router is a device that performs the functions of a router and also includes
the functions of a Wi-Fi access point.

ANT.doc:
A transducer designed to transmit or receive electromagnetic (e.g., TV or radio)
waves.

WIFIANT.doc: An access point compliant with either 802.11b, 802.11g, or 802.11ac.

WIFIAP.doc:
A wireless access point (WAP), or more generally just access point (AP), is a
networking hardware device that allows other Wi-Fi devices to connect to a wired
network.

FLOOR.doc: Any level part of a building with a floor used by people

BSMNT.doc:
Subterranean floor, also known as a basement or cellar is one or more floors
of a building that are completely or partly below the ground level.

PENT.doc:
A floor, typically located directly under a flat-roof, that houses mechanical
equipment

PRKLVL.doc: A floor or level on which parking takes place.

Relative humidity (RH) is the ratio of the partial pressure of water vapor to
the equilibrium vapor pressure of water at a given temperature. Relative humidity
depends on temperature and the pressure of the system of interest.

AHMS.doc: A device that measures the humidity of the air around it

AQS.doc: A device that monitors air quality in a defined area

WDS.doc: A sensor device that detects the presence of water

EQS.doc:

OAS.doc:

CAMPUS.doc:
A campus is a collection of two or more buildings that function as a single property.
They are generally owned and operated by the same party.

NET.doc: A digital telecommunications network which llows nodes to share resources.

CLINET.doc:
A computer and device network is a digital telecommunications network, specifically
segmented to the clinical systems in a healthcare facility,  which allows nodes
to share resources.

COMPNET.doc:
A computer network is a digital telecommunications network which allows nodes
to share resources.

DEVNET.doc:
A device network is a digital telecommunications network which allows nodes to
share resources.

ACU.doc: Air Conditioning Unit: An AHU than uses DX Cooling and Gas Heating.

AHU.doc:
Air Handling Unit: An enclosure with a fan that delivers air to a space via ductwork
and performs one or more of the functions of cleaning, heating, cooling, humidifying,
dehumidifying, ventilating or circulating the air.

AHUDFVCO.doc:
VAV Air Handlers are ideal for providing cool conditioned air to zones in a commercial
building.

AHUDFVCOECEFV.doc: VAV Air Handlers w/ Economizer and Variable Exhaust Fan

AHUDFVCOECPH.doc: VAV Air Handlers w/ Economizer and Hot Water Preheat

AHUDFVCOECPHEFV.doc: VAV Air Handler w/ Economizer, Hot Water Preheat, & Variable Exhaust Fan

AHUWSHPDZ.doc:
A single-zone air handling equipment that is a water-to-air heat pump using liquid
circulating in a neutral temperature loop functioning as a heat source/heat sink.

ahu.doc: Marker labels a dict with typing information

AHUWSHP.doc:
An air handling equipment that is a water-to-air heat pump using liquid circulating
in a neutral temperature loop functioning as a heat source/heat sink that serves
2 or more zones.

ahu.doc: Marker labels a dict with typing information

CRAC.doc: Computer Room Air Conditioner: An FCU designed to condition a computer room.

CRAH.doc: Computer Room Air Conditioner: An AHU designed to condition a computer room.

DOAS.doc:
Dedicated Outside Air System: An AHU that brings in 100% outside air and no recirculated
air in order to provide ventilation to spaces.

RTU.doc: Roof Top Unit: A unitary AHU that is weatherized for outdoor use.

ahu.doc: Marker labels a dict with typing information

CDDT.doc: Conduit used to convey Cold air.

DAD.doc:
Equipment used to regulate the amount of air entering the space. Typically found
in a VAV or MZU.

DADUCT.doc: Conduit used to convey air for on the Discharge side of the airside process.

DAF.doc: Fan equipment or control point located in the Discharge Air Duct

DMP.doc: Equipment used to regulate flow of air.

DUCT.doc: Generic Base class of conduit used to convey air.

EAD.doc: Equipment use to regulate the amount of air exhausted from the space or building.

EADT.doc: Conduit used to convey air for on the Discharge side of the airside process.

EF.doc: Fan equipment or control point located in the Exhaust Air Duct

EHC.doc:
Heat exchanger used to heat air using electricity as the source. Coils are sub-components
of HVAC equipment such as airHandlingEquip.

FANW.doc: A group of fans that are arranged in a wall and controlled together.

DFANW.doc: A discharge fan wall. See definition for fan wall.

EFANW.doc: An exhaust fan wall. See definition for fan wall.

RFANW.doc: A return fan wall. See definition for fan wall.

GEF.doc:
Fan used to remove contaminated air, specifically carbon monoxide from a space
where motor vehicles are used such as a garage.

GHC.doc:
Heat exchanger used to heat air using natural gas as the source. Coils are sub-components
of HVAC equipment such as airHandlingEquip.

HTDT.doc: Conduit used to convey Hot air.

MAD.doc: Equipment use to regulate the mixture of outside and return air before the DF.

MADUCT.doc:
Conduit used to convey air, blending outside air and return air prior to the
heating and cooling process.

OAD.doc: Equipment use to regulate the amount of outside air entering the space or building.

OADUCT.doc: Conduit used to convey outside air.

OF.doc: Fan equipment or located in the Outside Air Duct

RAD.doc:
Equipment use to regulate the amount of return air routed back to the space or
building.

RADUCT.doc: Conduit used to convey air for on the Return side of the airside process.

RF.doc: Fan equipment or control point located in the Return Air Duct

SF.doc: Fan equipment or control point located in the Discharge Air Duct

BRSEL.doc:
An integral part of a VRF system, the branch selector box will send either hot
gas (Heating mode) or Low pressure liquid (Cooling mode) to the indoor fan coil.

CAV.doc:
Constant air volume (CAV) is a type of heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning
(HVAC) system where the supply air flow rate is constant, but the supply air
temperature is varied to meet the thermal loads of a space.

HP.doc:
An air handling equipment which employs a vapor compression cycle with a reversing
valve to provide heating or cooling to a space.

MAU.doc:
Make Up Air Unit: A larger air handler that conditions 100% outside air, and
no recirculated air to make up for air lost from exhausted air.

VRFOU.doc: The outdoor unit of a VRF System, comprising one or multiple compressors.

VRFOUACHP.doc:
The outdoor unit of a heat pump VRF System, comprising one or multiple compressors.
The outdoor unit utilizes an air-cooled condenser to reject (or absorb) heat
to ambient air.

VRFOUACHR.doc:
The outdoor unit of a heat recovery VRF System, comprising one or multiple compressors.
The outdoor unit utilizes an air-cooled condenser to reject (or absorb) heat
to ambient air.

VRFOUWCHP.doc:
The outdoor unit of a heat pump VRF System, comprising one or multiple compressors.
The compressors are cooled by condenser water.

VRFOUWCHR.doc:
The outdoor unit of a heat recovery VRF System, comprising one or multiple compressors.
The outdoor unit utilizes a water-cooled condenser to reject (or absorb) heat.
Note that this unit does not strictly need to be outdoors as it is water-cooled.

VRFSYS.doc:
A typical system consists of an outdoor unit (comprising one or more skids containing
a compressor and condenser) and several indoor units (often called "fan coils").
The system is connected by refrigerant piping and comm wire running from the
outdoor units to all indoor units.

FCU.doc:
Fan Coil Unit: A unitary, factory-made enclosure with a fan and coil that recirculates
air in a space and performs one or more of the functions of cleaning, heating,
cooling, humidifying, dehumidifying, or ventilating the air. Unit heaters are
examples of FCUs.

FCUDACO.doc: FCU with chilled water cooling-only (discharge control).

FCUVRFZC.doc: FCU with DX heating and cooling and part of VRF System (zone control).

FCUZC.doc: FCU with chilled water cooling and hot water heating (zone control).

FCUZCCO.doc: FCU with chilled water cooling-only (zone control).

FCUZCHOE.doc: FCU with electric heating only (zone control).  Also referred to as a Unit Heater.

VAV.doc:
Variable air volume (VAV) is a type of heating, ventilating, and/or air-conditioning
(HVAC) system.

VAVCDAFC.doc:
VAV terminal unit that delivers air to downstream equips, typically 1 or more
chilled beams.

VAVCO.doc: VAV terminal unit that is supplied cool air from an AHU.

VAVEH.doc: Single duct reheat VAV with electric heat.

VAVHO.doc: VAV terminal unit that is supplied warm air from an AHU.

VAVPDRH.doc: Pressure Dependent VAV with Hot Water Reheat

VAVRH.doc: Single duct reheat VAV with dual setpoint control.

VAVV.doc: VAV used to deliver outside air to a given space or process.

SAV.doc: Supply air valve for zone pressure control, typically used in labs.

directZone.doc: Marker labels a dict with typing information

SAVRH.doc: Supply air valve for zone pressure control with hot water reheat.
